options: virtual seminar or other discussion format

narratives.question_text:
What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: 26 core learning mechanisms that can be employed in the classroom for enhanced learning!
I learned over 20 mechanisms for how children learn! These involved things such as analogies, belonging, contrasting cases, and many more!
Schwartz et al. (2016)'s A-Z core mechanisms and how to apply them to teach elementary and middle school students
I learned about 26 different teaching strategies/scaffolds that can help primary school students retain and understand information better.
Core learning mechanisms that influence a childrens experience in K-8 schooling.
Learning mechanisms for K-8 children

I learned so much from this class. Not only did we read and discuss the role of learning mechanisms but we also were able to hone our own skills as teachers through the act of teaching a class as well as observing our peers teach. The additional readings to the Schwartz text also helped us interpret empirical findings and how they relate to learning outcomes in the classroom.
I learned about learning mechanisms that are scientifically backed as being effective for K-8th graders.

I learned about how I want to be taught and how I think that all students should be taught. Our class focused on learning principles and everything that we learned about the best way to teach children should be applied in all schools at all ages.

I learned all about the different learning mechanisms and teaching strategies that can be applied to classrooms in order to enhance learning! I also learned about what teaching approaches are ineffective for students, as well as for specific subjects/areas of learning.
overview of practical & conceptual mechanisms that help children learn, especially K-8th grade students

narratives.question_text:
What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: I absolutely loved how this class was led by student presentations every week. We were able to learn in depth about one topic and then present it to our classmates. Then, we could discuss with each other and ask questions. Professor Lockhart was always ready to ask us questions and engage with us!

I liked how engaging and fun the course was. Every week, a couple students presented on one of the "ABCs of learning," which included mechanisms like using Analogies (A) and Just-in-Time Telling (T). The presentations were really interactive, with psychological experiments, quizzes and discussion questions embedded. I feel like I will remember practical use cases for many of these mechanisms far in the future because of how well-done the presentations were! The only drawback is that we didn't have much of an opportunity to apply what we learned, which is something I would have liked to see. Our final paper was a mock curriculum, but it would have been cool if we actually had a chance at some point to practice teaching via one of the mechanisms.

A strength of this course was a strong syllabus of readings as well as an intuitive and helpful sequence of topics.

A weakness of the course was the over-reliance on student presentations. Each class consisted of nearly two hours worth of student presentations.

Strengths: Easy to follow format, very engaging with EDST scholars, balances psychology and education studies fantastically! Easy to manage workload. Love that it met once a week; classes seemed to fly because of how interesting the content was and being able to apply personal experience.

Weaknesses: More direction on final assignment.
Absolutely flawless class.

I wish more of the teaching was done by Professor Lockhart! She is very knowledgeable and clearly has a lot to share. The format of the class meant that every class was a student presentation. While this allowed us to all be teachers ourselves, it also meant our quality of learning was up to the presenters of the day.

Strengths: the thought questions always felt very relevant and interesting to write about, and the student presentations were very engaging + helping in  understanding what the actual learning mechanisms we read about looked like

Weaknesses: sometimes the different assigned readings were a little repetitive in content

Professor Lockhart is clearly an expert in her field! Unfortunately, this is somewhat overshadowed by the abundance of student presentations. I wished I could hear more from her, rather than my classmates.

narratives.question_text: Among the practices in this course geared toward learning during the COVID-19 pandemic, which succeeded and which could be improved? Please comment on course practices that allowed for virtual engagement. (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Student presentations/lectures through sharing screen worked out beautifully!
It was hard to not be in the same room for presentations with classmates. Some activities would have been easier in person (hands-on activities for learning).

Interactive presentations are a must! This made the class very engaging. Professor Lockhart also did a great job facilitating discussion. Sometimes the discussions were a little shallow though and I felt like we could have engaged with the material more rigorously.
No improvements.

This course facilitated a warm and welcoming environment and it was very apparent had student's mental health in mind. The readings and responses were engaging but manageable, and the instructor went out of her way to offer us feedback leading up to the final project (even offering to meet outside of class).

narratives.question_text:
Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: MOST DEFINITELY. 100%!! Unfortunately, Professor Lockhart is retiring this year, but if this course is ever taught again by another professor, the course material itself is enough reason to take the course!
Definitely! Such great content to learn about children's learning.
Yes. LOVE PROF LOCKHART SO MUCH

Yes! If you have any inkling of teaching primary school in the future, this course is a must take. I think though that this is Professor Lockhart's last year of teaching, so I suggest that you research the future professor thoroughly, because there are definitely ways that the material can be dry if the professor isn't intentional about making the material engaging. You will learn practical skills that you can apply in the classroom or even for yourself as you're navigating student life!
I would recommend this course if the format changes to allow for more direct instruction from the instructor. The student presentation format did not facilitate my learning experience.
Yes! Great for future educators and those who wish to be involved directly with schools/children in the future.
YES!!!!!!!!! Every student must take.

YES! I am so sad the professor is retiring, but I hope this course will continue to be offered. If it isn't, I think the Schwartz book should be a required reading for first years the summer before they arrive at Yale, because the mechanisms are meant to be applied to strengthen ones own learning just as much as it is to design an effective class/teaching style. The class itself is such a nice place to be where it's very evident that learning and student engagement are a priority. The reading response questions were really meant to get you to think, and it's a privilege to be able to be taught by classmates who are also interested in the field of Education.
If you are interested in going into teaching, I think yes! It can give you a great amount of exposure to learning mechanisms that you may not have been familiar with.

Yes I would recommend this course to another student because the teacher is engaging and she truly shows that she wants all of us to learn. The workload is manageable and the material really requires students to think about how best they learn individually and do a lot of self-reflection. I loved this course and I would definitely recommend it !

Yes! This is a great course to take, especially if you are interested in becoming a  teacher in the future. It is also a great course because it helps you become more critical about your own learning experiences + helps you consider how you can improve your learning on your own with different techniques.
Yes! It is not too overwhelming, but it is definitely still interesting and applicable. If you want to be a teacher, this is a must-take!
